question: In Mycobacterium marinum-infected zebrafish, do granulomas form normally when TNF signaling is absent? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Thus, TNF is not required for tuberculous granuloma formation, but maintains granuloma integrity indirectly by restricting mycobacterial growth within macrophages and preventing their necrosis.
content.source_2: CRISPR/Cas9 ablation of tnfa in larval zebrafish prevented the initiation of organized granulomas; infected macrophages failed to aggregate and instead dispersed throughout tissues, and no granulomatous structures were detected by confocal imaging up to 7 days post-infection.
content.source_3: In the absence of TNF, intracellular bacterial growth and granuloma formation were accelerated and was followed by necrotic death of overladen macrophages and granuloma breakdown.
content.source_4: Contrary to prior reports, morpholino-mediated knockdown of TNF signaling yielded only amorphous leukocyte aggregates that lacked the concentric architecture of a normal granuloma. Restoration of TNF rescued granuloma development, indicating TNF is essential for formation rather than merely for maintenance.
